title: Taxonomy
description:
The science of classifying organisms based on shared characteristics.
Example: Classification of lion as Panthera leo

title: Systematics
description:
The study of biological diversity and evolutionary relationships among organisms.
Example: Birds evolved from theropod dinosaurs

title: Nomenclature
description:
Rules for naming organisms scientifically.
Example: Humans are Homo sapiens

title: Binomial Nomenclature
description:
Two-part scientific naming system including genus and species names.
Example: Canis lupus for gray wolf

title: Cladistics
description:
Classification method based on common ancestry and evolutionary branching.
Example: Cladogram showing primates and rodents diverging

title: Phylogeny
description:
Evolutionary history and relationships among species.
Example: Phylogenetic tree of vertebrates

title: Hierarchical Classification
description:
Ranking organisms into nested groups like Kingdom, Phylum, etc.
Example: Birds belong to Class Aves

title: Taxonomic Rank
description:
Levels of classification in biological hierarchy.
Example: Order Carnivora for felines

title: Monophyletic Group
description:
Group including a common ancestor and all its descendants.
Example: Mammals as a monophyletic group

title: Paraphyletic Group
description:
Group including a common ancestor but not all descendants.
Example: Reptiles excluding birds

title: Kingdom
description:
Highest taxonomic rank grouping organisms with fundamental similarities.
Example: Animalia for animals

title: Phylum
description:
Major division below Kingdom grouping organisms with similar body plans.
Example: Chordata for animals with backbones

title: Class
description:
Taxonomic group within a phylum.
Example: Mammalia includes mammals

title: Order
description:
Subdivision of class grouping families with shared traits.
Example: Carnivora includes cats and dogs

title: Family
description:
Taxonomic group containing related genera.
Example: Felidae includes lions and tigers

title: Genus
description:
Group of related species sharing common traits.
Example: Canis includes wolves and dogs

title: Species
description:
Most specific rank representing organisms that can interbreed.
Example: Homo sapiens for humans

title: Subspecies
description:
Division of species with minor genetic differences.
Example: Panthera leo persica for Asiatic lions

title: Superfamily
description:
Taxonomic rank above family grouping multiple related families.
Example: Hominoidea includes humans and great apes

title: Infraorder
description:
Taxonomic level between order and family.
Example: Cetacea for whales and dolphins

title: Convergent Evolution
description:
Process where unrelated species evolve similar traits.
Example: Wings in birds and bats

title: Divergent Evolution
description:
Evolution where related species develop different traits.
Example: Darwin's finches

title: Homology
description:
Traits inherited from a common ancestor.
Example: Pentadactyl limb in mammals and birds

title: Analogy
description:
Traits serving similar functions but from different origins.
Example: Shark and dolphin fins

title: Vestigial Structures
description:
Features that lost their original function over time.
Example: Human appendix

title: Adaptive Radiation
description:
Rapid diversification of a single lineage into multiple species.
Example: Galápagos finches

title: Phylogenetic Tree
description:
Diagram showing evolutionary relationships.
Example: Tree illustrating primate evolution

title: Clade
description:
Group of organisms including an ancestor and all descendants.
Example: Tetrapoda includes amphibians and mammals

title: Outgroup
description:
Species outside the primary study group, used for comparison.
Example: Sharks as outgroup for bony fish

title: Sister Taxa
description:
Two taxa sharing an immediate common ancestor.
Example: Humans and chimpanzees

title: Eutherian
description:
Placental mammals.
Example: Dogs, whales, and humans

title: Metatherian
description:
Marsupial mammals.
Example: Kangaroos and koalas

title: Monotreme
description:
Egg-laying mammals.
Example: Platypus and echidna

title: Arthropod
description:
Invertebrates with segmented bodies and exoskeletons.
Example: Spiders, crabs, insects

title: Cnidarian
description:
Aquatic animals with stinging cells.
Example: Jellyfish and corals

title: Mollusk
description:
Soft-bodied animals, many with shells.
Example: Snails and octopuses

title: Echinoderm
description:
Marine invertebrates with radial symmetry.
Example: Starfish and sea urchins

title: Chordate
description:
Animals with a notochord at some stage of development.
Example: Frogs and birds

title: Amphibian
description:
Cold-blooded vertebrates living in water and on land.
Example: Frogs and salamanders

title: Reptile
description:
Cold-blooded, scaly-skinned vertebrates.
Example: Snakes and lizards

title: Bird
description:
Warm-blooded vertebrates with feathers.
Example: Sparrows and eagles

title: Mammal
description:
Warm-blooded vertebrates with hair or fur.
Example: Humans and lions

title: Herpetology
description:
Study of amphibians and reptiles.
Example: Study of snakes

title: Ornithology
description:
Study of birds.
Example: Migratory bird studies

title: Ichthyology
description:
Study of fish.
Example: Marine fish taxonomy

title: Entomology
description:
Study of insects.
Example: Ant behavior studies

title: Paleontology
description:
Study of fossils to understand ancient life.
Example: Dinosaur fossil studies

title: Extinction
description:
Process where a species ceases to exist.
Example: Dinosaurs

title: Endemism
description:
Species restricted to specific regions.
Example: Lemurs in Madagascar

title: Invasive Species
description:
Non-native species disrupting ecosystems.
Example: Cane toads in Australia

title: Ecological Niche
description:
The role and position a species has in its environment.
Example: Bees pollinating flowers.

title: Population Genetics
description:
Study of genetic variation within populations.
Example: Genetic drift in island birds.

title: Speciation
description:
The process by which new species arise.
Example: Darwin’s finches diverging on the Galápagos Islands.

title: Gene Flow
description:
Transfer of genetic material between populations.
Example: Migration of wolves spreading genes.

title: Genetic Drift
description:
Random changes in allele frequencies in populations.
Example: Bottleneck effect in cheetahs.

title: Biodiversity
description:
The variety of life forms in an ecosystem.
Example: Rainforests with diverse species.

title: Phylogenetic Analysis
description:
Study of evolutionary relationships using genetic data.
Example: Determining bird evolution using DNA.

title: Cladogram
description:
Diagram depicting evolutionary relationships.
Example: A cladogram showing primate divergence.

title: Morphology
description:
The study of the form and structure of organisms.
Example: Comparison of bird beak shapes.

title: Homologous Structures
description:
Features inherited from a common ancestor.
Example: Forelimbs of bats and whales.

title: Analogous Structures
description:
Features with similar functions but different evolutionary origins.
Example: Wings of birds and insects.

title: Vestigial Organs
description:
Structures with reduced or no function.
Example: Human tailbone (coccyx).

title: Adaptive Evolution
description:
Changes in traits that improve survival and reproduction.
Example: Camouflage in chameleons.

title: Evolutionary Tree
description:
Diagram illustrating species divergence.
Example: Tree showing mammal evolution.

title: Dichotomous Key
description:
Tool for identifying species using contrasting features.
Example: Key to identify fish species.

title: Reproductive Isolation
description:
Mechanisms preventing species from interbreeding.
Example: Temporal isolation in frogs.

title: Sympatric Speciation
description:
Speciation occurring in the same geographic area.
Example: Cichlid fish in African lakes.

title: Allopatric Speciation
description:
Speciation due to geographic separation.
Example: Squirrels separated by the Grand Canyon.

title: Molecular Phylogenetics
description:
Study of evolutionary relationships using molecular data.
Example: Comparing DNA sequences in mammals.

title: Extinction Event
description:
Mass extinction of species.
Example: Cretaceous-Paleogene extinction of dinosaurs.

title: Endemism
description:
Species restricted to a specific region.
Example: Kangaroos in Australia.

title: Ecotype
description:
A population adapted to specific environmental conditions.
Example: Alpine plants on mountain slopes.

title: Biogeography
description:
Study of species distribution across geographic areas.
Example: Wallace's line separating Asian and Australian fauna.

title: Evolutionary Adaptation
description:
A trait that evolves due to natural selection.
Example: Thick fur in Arctic foxes.

title: Coevolution
description:
Two or more species evolving in response to each other.
Example: Flowers and their pollinators.

title: Habitat Fragmentation
description:
Breakup of habitat into smaller pieces.
Example: Deforestation affecting tiger populations.

title: Conservation Biology
description:
Study to preserve biodiversity.
Example: Efforts to save the Bengal tiger.

title: Mimicry
description:
One species evolving to resemble another.
Example: Viceroy butterflies mimicking monarchs.

title: Cryptic Species
description:
Species that look identical but are genetically distinct.
Example: Cryptic frogs in the Amazon.

title: Ecological Succession
description:
Gradual change in ecosystem structure over time.
Example: Colonization of lava fields by plants.

title: Keystone Species
description:
A species with a disproportionate impact on its ecosystem.
Example: Wolves controlling prey populations.

title: Founder Effect
description:
Loss of genetic variation in small populations.
Example: Island populations of birds.

title: Bottleneck Effect
description:
Drastic reduction in population size affecting genetic diversity.
Example: Northern elephant seals after hunting.

title: Natural Selection
description:
Process where organisms with favorable traits survive and reproduce.
Example: Peppered moth color change.

title: Artificial Selection
description:
Human-driven selection of traits.
Example: Breeding of domestic dogs.

title: Sexual Selection
description:
Selection based on traits that improve mating success.
Example: Peacock tail feathers.

title: Mutation
description:
A change in DNA that creates genetic variation.
Example: Mutation leading to antibiotic resistance.

title: Transitional Fossils
description:
Fossils showing intermediate traits between groups.
Example: Archaeopteryx linking dinosaurs and birds.

title: Ecological Isolation
description:
Species in the same area but occupying different niches.
Example: Bird species preferring different trees.

title: Temporal Isolation
description:
Species reproducing at different times.
Example: Frogs mating in different seasons.

title: Behavioral Isolation
description:
Differences in mating behavior preventing interbreeding.
Example: Birds with unique mating calls.

title: Hybridization
description:
Interbreeding of two different species.
Example: Liger, offspring of a lion and tiger.

title: Genetic Divergence
description:
Accumulation of genetic differences between populations.
Example: Genetic drift in isolated island species.

title: Polymorphism
description:
Occurrence of two or more forms within a species.
Example: Color variations in peppered moths.

title: Phenotypic Plasticity
description:
Ability of an organism to change traits in response to environment.
Example: Leaves adapting to light conditions.

title: Cline
description:
A gradual change in a trait across a geographic area.
Example: Size variation in mammals along latitudes.

title: Parallel Evolution
description:
Independent evolution of similar traits in species with a common ancestor.
Example: Flying squirrels in different continents.

title: Directional Selection
description:
Selection favoring one extreme of a trait.
Example: Giraffes with longer necks.

title: Stabilizing Selection
description:
Selection favoring average traits.
Example: Human birth weight extremes being unfavorable.

title: Disruptive Selection
description:
Selection favoring both extremes over the average.
Example: Finches with small or large beaks.
